facts.text: Appellant charged under s. 302 IPC for murdering his aunt Ratni, her daughter Chamin, her son-in-law Somra, and Dilu son of Somra.
Appellant convicted and sentenced to death by Judicial Commissioner of Chotanagpur.
Patna High Court accepted death reference (No. 9 of 1964), confirmed conviction and sentence, dismissed appellant's appeal (Criminal Appeal No. 200 of 1964) on November 9, 1964.

Prosecution case: On August 11, 1963 between 7 a.m. and 8 a.m., appellant murdered Somra in Dungijharan Hills forest, then Chamin in Kesari Garha field, then Ratni and Dilu in Ratni's house at village Jamtoli.
First information of offences lodged by appellant himself at PS Palkot on August 11, 1963 at 3:15 p.m., reduced to writing by SI H.P. Choudhury, appellant affixed left thumb impression.
SI took cognizance, arrested appellant immediately.
Next day (August 12, 1963), SI with appellant went to Ratni's house; appellant pointed out dead bodies of Ratni and Dilu, and place in orchard concealed with bushes and grass where he hid tangi.
Appellant took SI and witnesses to Kesari Garha khet, pointed out Chamin's dead body in ditch covered with Ghanghu.
Appellant took SI and witnesses to Dungijharan Hills, pointed out Somra's dead body on slope to the north.
SI recovered from appellant's house a chadar stained with human blood.
Evidence of PW 6: Appellant went to forest on morning of August 11, 1963.
Medical evidence: Incised wounds on all dead bodies caused by sharp-cutting weapon such as tangi. All four persons brutally murdered. No eyewitness to murders.
Principal evidence against appellant: First information report containing full confession of guilt. Without it, other evidence insufficient to convict.
FIR details motive: Quarrels due to aunt giving property to daughter and son-in-law; appellant believed on her death he and brother would own lands.

legal_issues.text: Whether the first information report (FIR), which contains a full confession of guilt by the appellant to a police officer, or any portion of it, is admissible in evidence under s.25 of the Indian Evidence Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Entire statement is a confession made to a police officer and not provable against appellant under s.25 Evidence Act.

respondent_arguments.text: s.25 protects only portions disclosing killings by appellant; rest of statement not protected by s.25.

court_reasoning.text: s.25 imperative: No confession to police officer admissible against accused under any circumstances. Covers confession whether free or in custody, before or after investigation begins.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Confession includes not only admission of offence but all incriminating facts related to it (motive, preparation, opportunity, etc.). Entire confessional FIR inadmissible except formal parts identifying maker and s.27 portions.

court_reasoning.text: Confession defined: Admission of offence or substantially all facts constituting it. Self-exculpatory parts cannot be separated if part of confessional whole.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Taint of confession under s.25 attaches to each part; cannot admit non-confessional parts separately.

court_reasoning.text: FIR as such not substantive evidence but can corroborate/contradict informant. If by accused, fact of giving it admissible as conduct under s.8; non-confessional FIR admissible as admission under s.21. But confessional FIR barred by s.25.
s.27 proviso lifts ban for information leading to discovery of facts, if accused in custody. Assume constructive custody here; thus portions leading to discovery of bodies and tangi admissible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Entire evidence now: Information as to places, discoveries, blood-stained chadar, appellant's presence in forest.

holdings.text: Save parts 1,15,18 (identifying appellant as maker) and s.27 portions (leading to discoveries), entire FIR excluded from evidence under s.25 Evidence Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Faddi v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Explaining non-confessional FIR by accused admissible under s.21 Evidence Act

precedents_cited.case_name: Nisar Ali v. State of U.P.

precedents_cited.relevance: Definition of confession discarded old definition; must admit offence or substantially all facts

precedents_cited.case_name: Palvinder Kaur v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Approved observations on confession; whole admission must be tendered

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Kathi Kalu Oghad
State of U.P. v. Deoman Upadhyaya
precedents_cited.relevance: Definition of confession; constructive custody under s.27
Whole admission including exculpatory part must be tendered

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Governing admissibility of confessions and admissions; s.25 bars confessional FIR

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: FIR recording; statements in investigation inadmissible except proviso/s.27

outcome.summary: Supreme Court partially allows appeal by excluding most of confessional FIR under s.25 Evidence Act, admitting only formal identification parts and s.27 discovery portions; remaining evidence consists of discoveries, blood-stained chadar, and appellant's forest visit.

key_quotes.text: "No confession made to a police officer, shall be proved as against a person accused of an offence."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.25 Evidence Act, central to holding

key_quotes.text: A confession may consist of several parts and may reveal not only the actual commission of the crime but also the motive, the preparation, the opportunity... If the confession is tainted, the taint attaches to each part of it.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A confession is an admission made at any time by a person charged with crime, stating or suggesting the inference that he committed that crime." (discarded definition)
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cites and rejects old definition per Pakala Narayanaswami
